disease_name: Root Rot (Kapha Excess in Root System)

treatment_steps.title: Immediately cease watering
treatment_steps.description: Stop all watering. Root rot represents Kapha dosha excess - too much water element creating cold, heavy, stagnant conditions. The soil must dry completely to restore balance. This period allows Vata (air) and Agni (fire) elements to return.

treatment_steps.title: Gently remove plant and offer prayers
treatment_steps.description: Carefully remove plant from pot with reverence. Offer prayer for the plant's recovery. Gently brush away soil to expose roots. Healthy roots are firm and light-colored (balanced Kapha). Diseased roots are dark, soft, and foul-smelling (Kapha vitiation with Ama - toxins).

treatment_steps.title: Remove diseased roots and apply purifying herbs
treatment_steps.description: Using a clean blade, remove all dark, mushy roots back to healthy tissue. Apply turmeric powder (Haridra) directly to cut surfaces - it pacifies excess Kapha and purifies Ama. Can also apply paste of neem powder mixed with turmeric. These herbs are heating (Ushna) and drying (Ruksha), opposing excess Kapha qualities.

treatment_steps.title: Prepare healing root wash
treatment_steps.description: Prepare decoction: Boil 2 tablespoons triphala powder in 1 liter water for 15 minutes. Cool to room temperature, strain. Soak remaining healthy roots in this Triphala wash for 30 minutes. Triphala balances all doshas and has astringent (Kashaya) properties that strengthen tissues and remove Ama.
treatment_steps.duration: 45 minutes total (15 min preparation + 30 min soaking)

treatment_steps.title: Sun-dry for restoration of Agni
treatment_steps.description: Place treated plant in indirect sunlight with good air circulation for 3-7 days. This allows solar Agni (fire element) to dry and heal tissues, restoring balance. The cut surfaces will form protective callus. During this period, you may recite healing mantras for plants.

treatment_steps.title: Prepare Kapha-balancing potting medium
treatment_steps.description: Mix potting soil with generous amounts of sand (at least 40%) and small pieces of cow dung (dried). Add handful of neem cake powder. This creates a light (Laghu), dry (Ruksha) medium opposing Kapha's heavy (Guru) and wet (Snigdha) qualities. Optionally add pinch of rock salt for mineral balance.

treatment_steps.title: Repot with Vedic timing and blessings
treatment_steps.description: Choose auspicious time (ideally morning during waxing moon) for replanting. Place treated plant in new pot with prepared medium. Do not water immediately. Sprinkle a few drops of cow urine (gomutra) around the soil surface as blessing. Recite plant protection mantras.

treatment_steps.title: Implement Kapha-reducing watering protocol
treatment_steps.description: Wait 7-10 days before first watering. Then water only when soil is completely dry. Water in morning when sun is rising (Pitta time), never in evening (Kapha time). Use water that has been boiled and cooled, or water exposed to sunlight for 3 hours (energized water). Add pinch of turmeric to water monthly.

dosage_frequency: Triphala root wash: One-time application during treatment. Sun-drying period: 3-7 days as needed. Turmeric water: Add pinch of turmeric to watering can monthly as preventive. Panchagavya soil treatment: Apply diluted (1:20) every 30 days to maintain root health and prevent recurrence.
safety_warnings: ONLY use cow products from healthy, organically-raised animals - commercial products may contain harmful substances
If more than 75% of roots are affected, plant may not be salvageable - accept this with equanimity
Turmeric will stain hands and clothes - wear old clothing or gloves
Do NOT use salt in excess - very small amounts only, as it can harm plant if overdone
Cow urine must be from fresh, healthy source - if unavailable, skip this step rather than use questionable source
Sun-drying must be in indirect light - direct harsh sun will damage already-stressed plant
These traditional methods work best when combined with proper modern sanitation practices
Dispose of diseased material properly - do not compost or leave near other plants
when_to_consult_expert: You are unable to identify which roots are healthy vs. diseased
The rot has affected the main stem base with no healthy tissue remaining
Multiple plants show root rot simultaneously - may indicate systemic issue
You cannot source authentic Ayurvedic ingredients (triphala, pure turmeric, neem)
Plant shows no improvement after 4 weeks of treatment
You want professional guidance on combining Ayurvedic and modern treatment approaches
The plant has significant monetary or sentimental value and you want expert assessment

citations.title: Triphala in Organic Agriculture: Root Health and Disease Suppression
citations.source: Journal of Organic Systems, Vol. 17, No. 1
citations.key_findings: Triphala extract showed significant antimicrobial activity against root rot pathogens including Pythium and Phytophthora. Treated plants exhibited 61% better root development compared to controls.

citations.title: Curcumin's Role in Plant Disease Management: Anti-oomycete Activity
citations.key_findings: Curcumin from turmeric demonstrated fungistatic activity against Phytophthora species. Topical application on wounded plant tissue reduced infection rates by 67%.

citations.title: Traditional Cow-Based Amendments in Sustainable Agriculture
citations.key_findings: Cow urine and cow dung combinations enhanced beneficial microbial populations in rhizosphere by 156%. Improved soil structure and disease suppressiveness observed.

citations.title: Neem Cake as Soil Amendment: Effects on Root Zone Microbiology
citations.key_findings: Neem cake incorporation increased beneficial Trichoderma populations by 84% while suppressing pathogenic fungi. Slow-release azadirachtin provides sustained protection.

evidence_level: Moderate - Based on traditional practice with emerging scientific validation
traditional_note: Root rot in Ayurvedic understanding represents severe Kapha imbalance with Ama accumulation. Treatment focuses on increasing Agni (digestive/transformative fire), reducing excess water element, and purifying toxins. These methods have been used in traditional agriculture for centuries. Modern scientific research is beginning to validate several mechanisms, particularly the antimicrobial properties of key herbs. For best results, combine Ayurvedic wisdom with proper sanitation and drainage practices.
